title-group.title: The 2D plasma potential distribution in a HiPIMS discharge
title-group.short-title: The 2D plasma potential distribution in a HiPIMS discharge
title-group.ej-title: The 2D plasma potential distribution in a HiPIMS discharge

address-group.address: Department of Electrical Engineering and Electronics, University of Liverpool, Brownlow Hill, Liverpool, L69 3GJ, UK
Surface Engineering Group, Dalton Research Institute, John Dalton Building, Manchester Metropolitan University, Chester Street, Manchester, M1 5GD, UK

abstract.heading: Abstract
abstract.p: Using an emissive probe the spatial-temporal distribution of the plasma potential Vp in a high power impulse magnetron sputtering discharge has been measured. The magnetron (with a planar circular titanium target) was operated in argon gas at a fixed pressure of 0.54 Pa, a pulse frequency of 100 Hz with a 100 µs on-time and average power of 650 W. In the early part of the voltage pulse (∼6–8 µs), Vp attains deep negative values (∼−150 V) at positions close to the target (10 mm) and above the racetrack, diminishing with distance, but never reaching ground potential, even at excursions of 80 mm. In the confined plasma region, extraordinarily high axial and radial electric field components, up to several kV m−1, are calculated from the plasma potential measurements.

As the plasma develops and the discharge current reaches a maximum (at ∼40 µs), Vp is elevated everywhere in the plasma, however, still with deep negative values (down to −40 V) at positions closest to the target. From the derived electric fields and modelled (vacuum) magnetic field, the 2D distribution of E × B electron drift velocities has been determined. During the early discharge phase, a broad drift channel is predicted above the racetrack, with drift speeds up to ∼3 × 105 ms−1 centred ∼30 mm above the target racetrack. As the discharge develops, these speeds reduce by about a factor 3 and the centre of the velocity distribution moves further away from the target and inwards towards the discharge axis, resembling that observed in dc and pulsed-dc magnetron operation.

sec-level1.heading: Introduction
sec-level1.p: High power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS) [1] is an interesting variant on conventional mid-frequency pulsed-dc sputtering, providing short duty cycles, but ultra-high peak powers leading to dense plasmas (up to 1019 m−3) with high fractions of the sputtered metal species being ionized [2, 3]. The technique is finding promise in a number of niche areas particularly in the production of engineering quality and high performance thin-films and coatings [1], including applications in non-reactive [4] and reactive [5, 6] sputtering, pre-treatment ion cleaning [7], and potentially in ion implantation [8].

Despite the growing interest in HiPIMS as a coatings tool, many of underlying physical and chemical processes are not well understood or are inadequately characterized. To address this a number of researchers have undertaken detailed diagnostic studies of the discharge, utilizing a variety of invasive and non-invasive diagnostic tools to yield information on: the bulk electron energies and densities [9–11], the ion bombarding energies [12–15], the total heat fluxes at the substrate [16], the plasma species composition (by optical emission, absorption or 2D imaging) [17, 18], currents in the plasma [19], plasma instabilities [20], and the electric potential and fields [21].

Although the charged particle densities and energies have been studied extensively, little is known about the structure and evolution of the electric potential (and field) throughout the HiPIMS plasma. The global structure of the plasma potential is particularly important, for it has already been seen in conventional magnetron sputtering (and in some recent HiPIMS studies) that it influences self-consistently the electron transport across the magnetic field [22], the structure of the circulating charged particle drifts [23], the distribution of negative ions in reactive sputtering [24], the trajectories of positive ions arriving at the cathode [25] and it determines to a large extent the energy of positive ions arriving at a grounded substrate [13, 26].

Using the Langmuir probe technique, detailed measurements of the temporal evolution of the plasma potential Vp have already been made at a limited number of positions (remote from the target) but close to the substrate in several HiPIMS discharge configurations [9, 13, 27–32]. In some cases only a mean figure for the plasma potential during plasma on-time [33, 34] is quoted, obtained as spot points in the time-resolved plasma measurement data set.

Although the magnitude of the measured values for Vp varies for different configurations and target materials, the results do show a consistent trend that Vp is most negative at the start of the pulse and grows more positive during the on-time. That is, climbing from initial values either close to ground (0 V) or in some configurations a few tens of volts below ground, up to values typically a few volts above ground. In the pulse off-time, Vp tends towards ground potential over typically several 100 µs as the plasma decays. These general trends were seen for instance in [27] where Vp was measured at −1 V in the bulk plasma (20 cm from the target) 40 µs after pulse initiation, becoming positive for the rest of the pulse period with peak values of Vp ∼ +5 V at the end of the ‘on-time’ (of duration of 100 µs). The time evolution of Vp has also been measured 9 cm from the target for a variation in working pressure in [29], with positive Vp values seen during the entire pulse period and higher Vp values (up to +5 V) obtained at lower pressure. These observations are consistent with the more limited results in [33, 34] showing Vp between +3 and +3.5 V in the pulse on-time. Generally, in the afterglow phase Vp is seen to decrease but still remain significantly above ground even at the end of the off-time (often durations >400 µs), for instance decreasing to ∼ +0.5 V [27] and between +1 and +1.7 V in [29]. Spatial-temporal measurements of Vp have also been made in [29] with Vp determined at three radial locations (r = 0, 5 and 7 cm from the discharge axis) in the plasma bulk. The results show, in this particular case, that Vp is almost spatially invariant with peak values of Vp ∼ +3.5 V at the end of the on-time (100 µs) at the chosen positions.

In a different HiPIMS discharge configuration [28], with a 200 µs pulse ‘on-time’, measurements showed Vp has two peaks per pulse period, with values of +2.5 V and +3.5 V, the first occurring in the ‘on-time’ (at ∼50 µs) and the second in the off-time (at ∼225 µs). It was also reported in the same publication that marginally higher discharge currents give rise to higher peak values of the Vp (e.g. +2.5 V at 5 A and +3.5 V at 50 A) measured in the afterglow (at 225 µs).

Although positive values of Vp are often found close to the substrate position in the driven phase of the discharge, this is not always the case. For instance, in non-reactive HiPIMS [9, 30] and reactive HiPIMS plasmas [30] it has been shown that during the on-time, even at remote positions from the target, Vp has values that are negative (e.g. −25 V at 100 mm and −21 V at 65 mm in [9, 30], respectively). These rise to values above ground potential in the off-time and more negative plasma potentials are observed in lower current discharges [30] in agreement with [28]. Negative plasma potentials in the early discharge phase have also been seen in a smaller device maintained by a simmer source [31, 32].

These results do convey useful information; however, little is known about the spatial structure of the plasma potential, or what the Vp values are at positions close to the target in HiPIMS plasmas. To address this, Mishra et al [21] used an emissive probe to make detailed spatially resolved measurements of Vp above the racetrack and along an axial line from a position close to the target up to a distance of 100 mm (typical position of a substrate). The emissive probe technique, which is superior to the Langmuir probe for determining Vp, was first used in the magnetron configuration by Thompson and co-workers [35].

The results in [21] showed that during the first few μs of the discharge (on-time duration 100 µs) Vp attained negative voltages (as deep as −210 V), at positions close to the target, but still outside the cathode sheath. With increasing distance from the target these values rise towards ground potential but never reach 0 V. As the discharge develops, these deep values collapse, but even at the time of maximum discharge current, Vp still attains negative values (−25 V) inside the closed-field of region the magnetic trap (a region of extension 50 mm from the target) with Vp rising up to +1 V at positions outside the trap close to the substrate. It was argued these large gradients in Vp (in the confined plasma) can act as a potential barrier so reducing the transport of the positively charged ions to the substrate, and lowering the deposition rate in HiPIMS.

Here, we use the emissive probe technique described in [21] to extend the 1D study to 2D, allowing us to map the plasma potential in most of the bulk plasma as a function of time during the discharge pulse. From this, it is possible to derive the electric field strength E. This will then allow us to better understand the ion dynamics in the discharge, namely the nature of any (electric potential) barrier to ion transport from target to substrate, but also provide information on particle drifts through construction of the distribution of azimuthal electron drifts by considering the E and B fields [35].

sec-level1.heading: Experimental details and procedure
sec-level1.p:
In this study a planar circular magnetron (V-TECH 150 from GENCOA Ltd) was used, equipped with a 150 mm diameter pure titanium (99.99%) target. The magnetron was housed in a purpose built vacuum chamber (70 cm in length and 40 cm in diameter) which was evacuated by a turbo-molecular pump backed by a rotary pump to a base pressure of 2 × 10−4 Pa. The magnetron was powered by a SINEX 3.0 HiPIMS power supply (from Chemfilt Ion Sputtering) and operated at a fixed frequency of 100 Hz and pulse on-time of 100 µs. The target was sputtered in argon gas (purity 99.99%) at a pressure of 0.54 Pa with a time-averaged power of 650 W. The peak target power and current densities were ∼0.6 kW cm−2 and ∼1.3 A cm−2, respectively. A schematic diagram of the magnetron arrangement, magnetic geometry and the area over which emissive probe measurements were made are shown in figure 1. The 2D magnetic field was measured using a Hall probe. One important region of the discharge is the magnetic trap, indicated in the figure and defined by a region enclosed by the magnetic field lines that intersect the target twice. The cathode voltage (Vd) and current (Id) waveforms were measured at an intermediary test box placed between the HiPIMS power supply and magnetron source using a ×100 voltage probe (Tektronix Ltd model P5100) and a ×20 current transformer (Tektronix Ltd Model CT-4) in conjunction with ×10 current probe (Tektronix Ltd Model TCP 202). These waveforms are shown in figure 2. A reference time t = 0 was defined as the zero voltage crossing point between the ‘off’ and ‘on’ phases of the voltage (Vd) pulse.
A schematic diagram of magnetron source, the magnetic field lines, the emissive probe, and the rectangular grid region where the measurements were carried out. The probe was inserted from the side port of the chamber.
The cathode voltage (Vd) and current (Id) waveforms produced by the SINEX 3.0 HiPIMS power supply for an average discharge power of 650 W and a gas pressure of 0.54 Pa.

The plasma potential Vp was measured using an emissive probe (described in detail in [21]) at 285 positions on a rectangular grid. These were over axial and radial distances of 10 ⩽ z ⩽ 80 mm and 0 ⩽ r ⩽ 90 mm, respectively, with a spatial resolution of 5 mm in both directions, see figure 1. Measurements in the cathode sheath and immediate pre-sheath regions adjacent to the target (i.e. z < 10 mm) could not be carried out since the probe strongly perturbs the plasma in this region, significantly lowering the discharge current. The emissive probe electrical arrangement and measuring circuitry used here are described in [21, 23, 25]. The emissive probe itself was made of a thoriated tungsten wire of diameter 125 µm, looped in a semicircle of diameter 2 mm and push-fitted into a ceramic housing containing enamelled copper connecting wires of 250 µm diameter that carry the external heating current. The probe loop was heated by passing a 50 Hz ac current through it, supplied by two separate transformers. The centre tap of the second transformer was connected to a fast oscilloscope (TDS3014, 1 MΩ input impedance, Tektronix Ltd) via a single strand wire (used to minimize the capacitance to ground) to obtain the mean voltage (floating potential) across the loop and hence a good estimate of Vp. The floating potential data was then averaged over 128 discharge pulses and then stored to minimize the random error in the electrical signal. The error in Vp using this method is estimated to be less than the voltage equivalent of the local electron temperature kTe/e [21, 36], with a temporal resolution better than 20 ns [36].

To ensure that sufficient heating current is applied to produce strong electron emission, giving reliable estimates of Vp, preliminary studies were conducted in which the probe floating potential was recorded as a function of the heating current. This was done at one particular position in the discharge (z = 30 mm, r = 45 mm) and at one chosen time in the pulse cycle (t = 7 µs) and for two angles of the probe relative to the local B-field. As shown in figure 3 a heating current of Ih = 2.5–3.5 A is required together with a probe-plane oriented parallel to the local magnetic field (___ENT___ = 0) for full electron emission to be achieved. At this condition Vf → Vp (i.e. Vf attains its most positive value). Issues concerned with the orientation of the emissive probe relative to the magnetic field are discussed further in [21].
A plot of measured emissive probe floating potential (Vf) versus loop heating current (Ih) at one position (z = 30 mm r = 45 mm) at the time of the ‘first peak’ (t = 7 µs) in two orientation of probe-plane with respect to B-field lines. It should be noted that at Ih > 2.5 A, the floating potential Vf approaches the plasma potential Vp.

From the plasma potential measurements the axial and radial components of the electric field can be derived namely Ez = −dVp/dz and Er = −dVp/dr. To estimate the azimuthal electron drift velocities the vector product (E × B)/B2 was calculated, using the vacuum magnetic field B measured on the bench top using a Hall probe. The probe resolves both the radial (Bz) and axial components (Br), respectively.

sec-level2.heading: Time-evolution of Vp in the bulk plasma
sec-level2.p:
Figure 4 shows the time-evolution of Vp measured at a position close to the typical position of substrate, z = 80 mm, r = 45 mm together with the discharge voltage waveform (Vd), with both traces recorded simultaneously on the oscilloscope. Vp readily responds to changes in Vd, sinking rapidly just after pulse initiation, and then climbing towards ground as the discharge develops. The initial phase of the on-time is characterized by three peaks in Vp, features however not seen in Vd, at potentials of −16, −14 and −13 V occurring at times t ∼ 7 µs, 17 µs and 25 µs, respectively. The times of these peaks jitter by ±1 µs throughout the pulse cycle. We denote these peaks as the ‘first’, ‘second’ and ‘third’ peaks' and speculation on the origin of these features is discussed briefly in [21].
A plot of the time-evolution of typical plasma potential (Vp) measured at one position (z = 80 mm and r = 45 mm) together with cathode discharge voltage Vd, at an average discharge power of 650 W and a gas pressure of 0.54 Pa. Here, we identify the ‘first peak’, ‘second peak’, ‘third peak’ and the time of the maximum in the discharge current ‘IDmax ’ (see figure 2). The discharge voltage reaches zero at t = 57 µs.

Inspection of figure 4 shows that at this probe position, Vp is negative for about half of the pulse on-time, rising to cross ground potential at t ∼ 57 µs, some 17 µs after the time of maximum current (see figure 2). After this, Vp reaches a plateau at ∼+4 V, a value consistent with other studies [27–29, 33, 34] before displaying a kink at t = 100 µs. The latter occurs at the point where Vd abruptly rises to 0 V as the pulse enters the off-time. In the afterglow, Vp decreases and stabilizes at ∼+2 V (and for whole of the pulse off-time, however, not shown). The finite positive plasma potentials in the off-time have been seen before in other HiPIMS plasmas and indicate the very slow decay of the plasma [31].

sec-level2.heading: 2D spatial distributions of Vp
sec-level2.p:
Figures 5(a), (b) and (c) show 2D maps of Vp at for three different times during the on-time, namely at the ‘first peak’ (t = 7 µs), ‘second peak’ (t = 17 µs) and also at the time of maximum discharge current (t = 40 µs). The direction of the magnetic field lines is represented by the arrows of unit length in each of the figures. In the first case, Vp is negative at almost all positions in the measured plane except in the remote outer region with values up to +4 V. Deep potentials (∼−150 V) are measured in a broad region above the racetrack and close to the target (10 < z < 15, 40 < r < 50 mm). With increasing distances from the target and moving radially outwards and towards the discharge axis Vp becomes more positive, forming approximately elliptically shaped equipotential lines, with the focus at r ∼ 45 mm, the position of maximum target erosion when the source is operated in dc and pulsed-dc modes [37]. The negative plasma potentials exhibit the steepest gradients inside the magnetic trap; the closed field region defined in figure 1, with axially downward and inward pointing electrical fields, calculated in excess of 1 kV m−1. This field structure (tangents to Vp equipotentials) essentially draws ions into the target from a wide region, funnelling them down to the racetrack. Outside the trap, in regions close to any substrate, the E-fields fall to below 0.4 kV m−1.
2D plots of the measured plasma potential Vp measured in volts at (a) the time of the ‘first peak’ (t = 7 µs), (b) the time of the second peak (t = 17 µs) and (c) at time of maximum current (t = 40 µs). The direction of the magnetic field lines is indicated by the arrows of unit length.

It is clear from figure 5(a) that at this time in the pulse cycle, there is a large plasma potential drop across the bulk plasma with ΔVp ∼ 140 V in a line above the racetrack. These values are significantly higher than those measured in conventional pulsed-dc magnetron sputtering discharges [23, 25, 35] and larger than the drop of ΔVp ∼ kTe/e predicted by the Bohm criterion (where Te is the electron temperature) required to accelerate ions to the ion acoustic speed in the pre-sheath as they enter the sheath [38]. We are assuming that kTe/e is only of the order of a few eV [9]; however, very high electron temperatures (>80 eV) have been observed in the period (t = 1–4 µs) preceding this first peak in Vp.

In figures 5(b) and (c) we see that at the time of the second peak in Vd (t = 17 µs) and later at the time of maximum current Id (t = 40 µs) the magnitude of the bulk plasma potentials reduce markedly above the racetrack and in the bulk. The deepest potentials recorded are about −40 V, 10 mm from the target. The bulk axial and radial electric fields' strengths decrease to several 100 V m−1; however, the field directions (tangents to Vp contours) still show there is still a marked funnelling of ions to the target. Downstream, at t = 40 µs (figure 5(c)), Vp is positive at the sides of the map (centreline and remote plasma), but still remains negative in a large region that would be occupied by a substrate (i.e. at z = 80 mm). One can see that as the discharge develops the centre of the equipotential contours shifts from r ∼ 45 mm to r ∼ 50 mm. In previous work it has been observed that when the magnetron is operated in HiPIMS mode the racetrack broadens compared to dc conditions [37]. The results here indicate that this is related to the different shape of the equipotential contours in HiPIMS and that the position of the centre of the racetrack moves during the HiPIMS pulse, in this case from 45 to 50 mm. Despite the reduced negative potentials with increased times, the potential drops across the plasma (ΔVp ∼ 40 V) remain much higher than predicted by the Bohm criterion for non-magnetized boundaries. Such anomalous behaviour of the pre-sheath has been observed in other magnetized systems including dc and pulsed-dc magnetron discharges [21, 25, 35] and has been predicted for low-pressure magnetron operation using Particle-in-Cell Monte Carlo collisional modelling [39] and fluid simulations incorporating classical electron diffusion rates [40]. It can be argued simply that the presence of the magnetic field perpendicular to the main electric field above the racetrack increases the cross-field resistivity necessitating self-consistently large potentials to drive electrons from the magnetic trap to the walls.

The results in figures 5(c) show that during the time of maximum sputtering, positive ions (post-ionized neutrals) created from a region close to the target would need a forward energy of about 40 eV and to surmount the potential hill above the racetrack to reach a substrate at z = 80 mm. Sputtered atoms characterized by the Sigmund Thomson energy distribution [38] ionized in magnetic trap will have a small probability of reaching the substrate as discussed in [21]. However, ions created outside the magnetic trap, even with small forward energies can readily reach the substrate, surmounting only ∼3 eV to do so. The presence therefore of the large variation plasma potential in the bulk may contribute to the reduced deposition rates observed in HiPIMS operation, with those ions reaching the substrate being ones only created locally.

sec-level2.heading: The distribution of electron E × B drifts velocities
sec-level2.p:
From the plasma potential measurements in figures 5(a) and (c), the electric field components Ez and Er of the have been calculated (shown in figure 6) using the central difference method. Along the discharge central axis at r = 0 mm, the boundary condition Er = 0 was imposed. At the time of the first peak in Vp (t = 7 µs), Ez has largest values at positions close to the cathode, as the potential gradient steepens approaching the cathode sheath region; however, interestingly this is not the case at the time of the maximum discharge current (t = 40 µs), where the largest Ez is found 40 mm from the cathode. Figure 6(d) shows clearly that in the phase of the discharge there is a reduction in Ez in the plasma bulk approaching the cathode. For axial distances <10 mm the potential must curve steeply down to the target potential. Such reductions in the bulk electric field and even reversals in potential leading to opposite sign electric fields have been predicted through modelling of HiPIMS discharges [22]. Here we see no reversal to positive electric fields, but this may be due to the relatively large distance between measurements. 1D plasma potential measurements in the same system [21] do, however, show some evidence of the existence of a triple layer close to the cathode in which there is a zero in Ez.
The electric field components Er (a) and Ez (b) at the time of the ‘first peak’ (t = 7 µs) and Er (c) and Ez (d) at time of maximum current (t = 40 µs).

Using the derived E-fields and the measured values of B (the unperturbed vacuum field), the vector field of the E × B electron drift velocity, vE×B = E × B/B2 can be calculated. The azimuthal component of this vector product is the electron Hall drift velocity, given as vH = (EzBr − BzEr)/B2 and velocity distributions corresponding to times at the first peak in Vp(t = 7 µs) and maximum discharge current (t = 40 µs), are shown in figures 7(a) and (b). One should note that the checked area shown at the top left hand corner of the contour plots is the region where |B| is small and the electrons are un-magnetized (their Larmor radii are greater than their distance from the discharge central line). Ions, which are un-magnetized, should have no E × B drift; however, recent observation in [15] shows that ions do in fact orbit above racetrack due to a net azimuthal force in the plasma, possibly driven by a two-stream instability.
2D plots of the E × B electron drift speeds at (a) the time of the ‘first peak’ and (b) the time of the maximum discharge current.

The two plots in figure 7 of the electron drift speeds show some similarities but also some clear differences. At the time of the first peak (t = 7 µs) we see a diagonal region of high drift speeds extending from r = 50 mm, z = 10 mm (above the racetrack) up and towards the discharge central axis at r = 35 mm z = 40 mm, with maximum drift speed found to be 3.25 × 105 ms−1 (a significant fraction of estimated thermal speed of ∼1 × 106 ms−1 assuming kTe/e ∼ 4 eV [[9]). As the discharge develops and at the time of maximum discharge current (t = 40 µs) these speeds reduce by about a factor 3 (as E falls) and the rectangular region of high drift speeds narrows and moves upwards and inwards, now extending from r = 40 mm, z = 45 mm to r = 20 mm, z = 65 mm. This distribution of electron drift velocity is similar to that measured during dc and pulsed-dc magnetron operation [35]. The small negative drift velocities close to discharge axis in figures 7(a) and (b) are due to imprecision in the measurement method and these must necessarily tend to zero. At radii greater than 75 mm the radial component of magnetic field changes sign leading to counter drifting electrons in the outer region.

The measured E × B drift speeds in the HiPIM mode at the time of the first peak (t = 7 µs) are about twice as large as those measured in dc operation [35] in the same magnetron. However, at the time of maximum current (t = 40 µs) there is much closer agreement between the different modes of operation. These speeds (up to 1.5 × 105 m−2) are marginally higher than the curvature drift and grad B drift speeds, their combination determined in the discharge ∼4 × 104 ms−1 [35]; these quantities being almost independent of the means of operation, since for a fixed magnetic field geometry they depend only on Te, which varies little between HiPIMS and dc modes, when the HiPIMS discharge reaches its quiescent driven phase. However, the calculated azimuthal electron drift speeds here are an order of magnitude higher than those determined in a different HiPIMS system developed in the group of Helmersson [20], where the drift speeds were obtained from knowledge of E (via spatial measurements of Vp). This HiPIMS plasma was characterized by having azimuthal electron current densities JH only two to four times larger than the discharge current density JD. This regime is described as ‘super-Bohm’ diffusion [19], where ratio JH/JD is significantly below the empirically determined Bohm value of 16.

In a system similar to that described in [20] but operating with a copper target rather than titanium, the current densities JH and JD were measured by Rogowski coil [19]. For different heights above the racetrack (z = 50 to 80 mm) the ratios JH/JD were found to lie mostly between 2 and 5, i.e. the discharge is operating in the ‘super-Bohm’ regime. At the time of maximum current the azimuthal current density was JH = 2 × 104 A m−2. However, in this work, at the time of maximum current JH (determined where vH is maximum, z = 50 mm) is somewhat larger than reported in [19], estimated to be JH ∼ 1.2 × 105 A m−2. With JD = 1.3 × 104 A m−2at this time in the discharge it gives a ratio of about JH/JD ∼ 11. Here we have assumed a plasma density of 6 × 1018 m−3 taken from [9]. So, our magnetron may be operating in a mode closer to Bohm diffusion as seen in dc discharges [35] rather than ‘super-Bohm’ as observed in [19, 20], but also in pulsed-dc magnetrons using a B-dot probe [41]. Clearly more work is required to understand better how anomalous electron transport is affected by geometry and operating conditions in HiPIMS discharges.

sec-level1.heading: Conclusions
sec-level1.p: Using the emissive probe technique, the spatial distribution of plasma potential Vp in a high power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS) discharge has been measured at different times during the 100 Hz pulse cycle with a 100 µs on-time. In the early part of the voltage pulse (∼7 µs), roughly semi-elliptical contours in Vp are seen above the racetrack with deep negative values (∼−150 V) being measured 10 mm from the target. With increasing axial distance Vp diminishes in magnitude, approaching but not reaching ground potential at distances up to 80 mm, demonstrating the existence of bulk electric field strengths of several kV m−1. As the discharge develops and at the time of maximum discharge current, the values of Vp collapse substantially but still remain negative with values down to −40 V some 10 mm from the target.

From the measured magnetic field and derived electric fields, the distribution of E × B electron drift velocities has been determined. In the initial discharge phase (∼7 µs), a broad drift channel above the racetrack is seen, with high drift speeds (∼3 × 105 m s−1) up to 40 mm from the target. As the discharge develops, these speeds reduce to ∼1 × 105 m s−1 and the drift channel (contours of velocity) move away from the target consistent with observations in dc and pulsed-dc magnetrons.

acknowledgment.heading: Acknowledgments
acknowledgment.p: The authors would like to thank the EPSRC for funding the research. One of the authors AM was awarded an ORSAS scholarship so aiding his study.

journal-ref.art-title: Internal Current Measurements in high power impulse magnetron sputtering

book-ref.book-title: Handbook of Sputter Deposition Technology: Principles, Technology, and Applications
